ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This was a good course. The readings could be long but they were doable. This is a good course if you are an anthropology major or if you just want to get a glimpse into what anthropology is like. A few writing assignments but they weren't too long.

Great class! Take it if you're interested in gaining philosophically abstract and ethnographically concrete perspectives on power/resistance, fear-terror, hope, space/time as they relate to violence, and racial hegemony. Come with an open mind and ready to work outside your comfort zone, if you're used to a specific discourse in anthropology or a specific disciplinary framework like quantitative social science, etc. Prof. Lombard is a great discussion starter, and she put a lot of creativity into creating a thoughtful syllabus. I would take this class again if given the chance.
Yes! The class engages with conflict in a rigorous and nuanced way.
